In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  For two decades, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has supported the efforts of the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC) and Mongolia to participate in regional cooperation. ADB has 
also supported PRC–Mongolia cooperation since 2001 through technical assistance (TA) projects, 
including the TA for  Development of Regional Cooperation Programs for  Mongolia and  the 
People’s Republic of China,1 which was completed in April 2010. This regional policy and advisory 
TA is proposed in response to requests by the two governments for ADB to continue its support 
for PRC–Mongolia cooperation. The TA concept was cleared on 31 March 2010, and the proposal 
for funding by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund was approved on 18 May 2010. 
The  fact-finding  mission  visited  the  PRC  and  Mongolia  17–21  May  2010  to  discuss  with 
government officials and other stakeholders the impact, outcome, outputs, and implementation 
arrangements for the TA. Consultations were also conducted with the two governments during the 
in-country workshops on regional cooperation held in Beijing and Ulaanbaatar. Broad agreement 
was  reached  on  the  key  aspects  of  the  TA,  and  support  was  obtained  for  its  design  and 
implementation (Appendix 1).2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The PRC and Mongolia attach great importance to regional cooperation and integration 
(RCI). Both countries participate in various RCI initiatives, including the ADB-led Central Asia 
Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) Program and the United Nations–led Greater Tumen 
Initiative  and  Northeast  Asia  Economic  Cooperation  Forum.  The  PRC  country  partnership 
strategy, 2008–20103 identified regional cooperation as one of the four key thrusts of ADB 
assistance,  whereby  ADB's  RCI  programs  will  be  used  to  enhance  regional  infrastructure 
connectivity, facilitate cross-border trade and investment, and promote regional public goods. 
The Mongolia country partnership strategy, 2010–20154 also treats regional cooperation as a 
crosscutting theme. Regional cooperation is vital to Mongolia, a landlocked country, as it offers 
opportunities  to  strengthen  infrastructure  and  trade  links  with  its  neighbors,  diversify  its 
economy, and realize its growth potential.  
 
3.  The PRC and Mongolia share a border of about 4,600 kilometers. The two countries have 
strong economic and trade complementarities. For more than a decade, the PRC has been 
Mongolia’s largest trading partner and investor. Bilateral trade has been growing quickly—from 
less than $100 million in 1990 to $2.4 billion in 2009.5 About 65% of Mongolia’s exports go to the 
PRC, while 35% of Mongolia’s imports come from the PRC. The PRC is also the biggest source of 
foreign direct investment in Mongolia; total PRC investment in Mongolia reached about $1 billion 
by the end of 2009. However, PRC–Mongolia trade and investment cooperation still faces various 
constraints, mainly insufficient transport infrastructure and services, cumbersome customs and 
other border procedures, and lack of coordination in border-area (including free economic zone) 
development. Mongolia suffers more from these constraints, because its economy relies more 
heavily on external markets.

4.  Mongolia’s rich endowments of natural resources, particularly minerals, could not only 
supply  the  PRC’s  growing  demand,  but  also  serve  overseas  markets.  This  represents 
tremendous opportunities for Mongolia to accelerate its economic transformation and diversify 
its export markets. However, the transportation connections between Mongolia and the PRC are 
not  adequate  to  exploit  the  full  economic  potential  of  these  resources.  The  PRC’s  Inner 
Mongolia Autonomous Region and northeastern provinces have invested massively in transport, 
particularly since 2000. These investments have greatly alleviated the capacity constraints that 
would otherwise have impeded Mongolia’s access to markets in the PRC and beyond. However, 
low physical capacity and insufficient investment continue to constrain the transport system in 
Mongolia, especially in the central corridor (CAREC corridor 4b), which leads to the PRC via 
Zamyn-Uud.6 The situation is exacerbated by slower-than-expected progress in implementing 
the PRC–Mongolia bilateral transport agreement and the absence of a PRC–Mongolia–Russian 
Federation tripartite transit transport agreement. The PRC–Mongolia transport agreement is 
being amended and is expected to be signed in late 2010. The major amendments are expected 
to cover such key issues as opening new transport routes and expanding the exchange of traffic 
rights. Both countries will need technical assistance to implement the agreement. Negotiation of 
the  tripartite  transit  agreement  began  in  2000  under  the  auspices  of  the  United  Nations 
Conference on Trade and Development. It has not reached a conclusion, and the negotiations 
on technical annexes  have yet to start. The PRC and Mongolia have  asked ADB to help 
revitalize the negotiations.  
 
5.  The  existing  cumbersome  and  ill-coordinated  cross-border  procedures  related  to 
customs, quarantine and inspection, transport inspection, and other border controls also impede 
trade by causing long delays at the border, especially at Zamyn-Uud, which, together with the 
PRC’s Erenhot (also known as Erlianhaote), serves as the gateway for PRC–Mongolia trade 
and transit trade with Europe and the Russian Federation. The initial findings from the CAREC 
corridor performance measurement and monitoring (CPMM) program indicate that a typical 500-
kilometer cross-border journey by a 20-ton truck can take as long as 33 hours, 9 hours of which 
is for waiting and queuing, 4 hours for loading and unloading, and 2.5 hours for customs 
clearance in Zamyn-Uud.  
 
6.  Another obstacle to trade is the uneven development in the border areas, particularly 
between Erenhot and Zamyn-Uud.7 To better harmonize border-area development, the local 
authorities in Zamyn-Uud and Erenhot have set up a dialogue mechanism to address cross-
border issues. However, this ad hoc mechanism lacks planning and monitoring, and therefore 
needs strengthening.  
 
7.  The  PRC  and  Mongolia  have  used  the  opportunities  offered  by  RCI  programs  to 
enhance their bilateral cooperation. The CAREC regional cooperation strategy also endorses 
bilateral  initiatives  that  have  a  broader  regional  impact.8 The  PRC–Mongolia  cooperation 
supported by ADB has been implemented in line with the broader CAREC objectives and 
related sector strategies. However, it is tailored to the special priorities of the two countries and 
is carried out in a flexible manner to meet the countries’ needs as they emerge. The original TA 
(footnote 1) supported a set of priority actions jointly identified by the PRC and Mongolia. Initial,

but important, achievements have been made, particularly in transport and trade facilitation. Key 
activities completed include a (i) study on harmonizing transport planning between the PRC and 
Mongolia, (ii) study on harmonizing trade logistics and border-town infrastructure development 
in Erenhot and Zamyn-Uud, and (iii) pilot test of the PRC–Mongolia joint customs control (JCC) 
at Erenhot and Zamyn-Uud through harmonization of cargo manifests for road transportation. 
The original TA recommended steps to deepen PRC–Mongolia cooperation that will need ADB’s 
continued support. The key recommendations include (i) reviewing the JCC pilot and expanding 
JCC to other border-crossing points, (ii) enhancing PRC–Mongolia transport cooperation by 
concluding  and  implementing  the  amended  transport  agreement,  (iii)  further  harmonizing 
border-area development by institutionalizing a dialogue mechanism at the key border cities of 
Zamyn-Uud and Erenhot, and (iv) exploring cooperation in inspection and quarantine areas. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The impact will be the increased efficiency of trade between the PRC and Mongolia 
resulting from enhanced regional cooperation. The outcome will be deepened PRC–Mongolia 
cooperation  in  the  priority  areas  of  customs,  quarantine,  transport,  and  border-area 
development; and experience sharing with other CAREC countries.  
 
9.  The impact and outcome will be achieved through the delivery of the following outputs: 
(i)  Output 1: Deepened PRC–Mongolia customs cooperation through 
(a)  review of the experience of the JCC pilot at Erenhot and Zamyn-Uud; 
(b)  replication of JCC at other selected border crossing points, with a special 
focus on facilitating Mongolia’s mineral exports;  
(c)  development  of  cooperation  initiatives  in  other  areas,  including 
simplification  of  customs  procedures,  data  exchange,  and  risk 
management;  
(d)  training for Mongolian customs at Shanghai Customs College; and 
(e)  promotion  of  JCC  experience  sharing  with  other  CAREC  countries, 
particularly those that are also pilot-testing JCC.  
(ii)  Output 2: Enhanced coordination in border-area development through 
(a)  establishment of a joint border-area development committee; 
(b)  cross-border dialogue for better planning and management of border-area 
development in Erenhot and Zamyn-Uud;  
(c)  organization of public–private sector dialogues and business forums to 
address  private  sector  needs  and  develop  public–private  partnership 
opportunities in Erenhot and Zamyn-Uud, particularly in trade logistics 
improvement;  
(d)  experience sharing on developing free economic zones; and  
(e)  launch of a joint website to share information on PRC–Mongolia trade and 
investment opportunities.  
(iii)  Output 3: Enhanced PRC–Mongolia transport cooperation through 
(a)  effective implementation of the amended PRC–Mongolia bilateral road 
transport agreement through progress review, experience sharing, and 
training, including producing operational user manuals;  
(b)  enhanced PRC–Mongolia policy dialogue in transport sector to further 
harmonize transport planning across the border and improve Mongolia’s 
access to seaports in the PRC; and

4     
(c)  recommendations  to  decision  makers  for  revitalizing  the  negotiation 
process of the tripartite transport agreement among the PRC, Mongolia, 
and the Russian Federation. 
(iv)  Output  4:  Establishment  of  a  mechanism  for  PRC–Mongolia  dialogue  and 
cooperation in inspection and quarantine to address sanitary and phytosanitary 
issues and quality and standard issues, particularly those related to the trade of 
agricultural and meat products.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The TA will undertake the following activities: 
(i)  organizing meetings of the PRC–Mongolia working group on JCC and workshops 
to review the progress of JCC pilots, and share experiences with other CAREC 
countries, particularly Kazakhstan;  
(ii)  organizing training at Shanghai Customs College for Mongolian (and Kazak) 
customs officers, particularly those from border customs houses, on selected 
customs cooperation topics; 
(iii)  organizing  consultations  to  help  the  PRC  and  Mongolia  establish  a  joint 
committee (and subcommittees, if necessary) for better coordination of border-
area  development  in  Erenhot  and  Zamyn-Uud,  and  organizing  committee 
meetings to strengthen cross-border dialogue;  
(iv)  conducting training (including workshops and study tours) on free economic zone 
development for Mongolian officials, with a view to accelerating the development 
of such a zone at Zamyn-Uud;  
(v)  organizing  public–private  sector  dialogues  and  business  forums  to  address 
private sector needs and develop  public–private partnership opportunities for 
border-area development;  
(vi)  establishing  a  joint  website  to  share  information  on  business  opportunities, 
business operation, and training;  
(vii)  organizing meetings, workshops, and other capacity building activities to support 
the  implementation  of  the  PRC–Mongolia  transport  agreement,  including 
producing  operational  manuals  for  different  user  groups,  and  improving  the 
existing PRC–Mongolia transport dialogue mechanism to facilitate dialogue at the 
decision-making level; 
(viii)  exploring ways to revitalize negotiations on the tripartite transit agreement among 
the  PRC,  Mongolia,  and  the  Russian  Federation  with  the  United  Nations 
Conference on Trade and Development and countries concerned;  
(ix)  establishing a platform for dialogue and cooperation between inspection and 
quarantine agencies of the two countries to address sanitary and phytosanitary 
issues and quality and standard issues related to cross-border trade; and  
(x)  organizing workshops for knowledge sharing with other CAREC countries. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $950,000 equivalent, of which $900,000 equivalent will be 
financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  Regional  Cooperation  and  Integration  Fund9 under  the 
Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility. The central and provincial 
governments of the PRC and Mongolia will each make in-kind contributions of about $25,000 
equivalent by  providing  counterpart  staff; office  space;  support for  training,  seminars,  and 
                                                
9  Established by ADB.

conferences; and other administrative and logistical services. Details of the cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  About 12 person-months of international and 20 person-months of national consultant 
services will be required to provide advisory and technical services under the TA. The consultants 
and resource persons will be specialists in integrated transport, trade, and investment facilitation; 
development planning and strategy formulation; private sector and business development; and 
institutional and capacity building. Because the TA will involve varied activities, consultants and 
resource  persons  will  be  selected  and  engaged  by  ADB  as  individuals  based  on  their 
qualifications and experience in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). Appendix 3 provides the outline terms of reference for 
consultants and resource persons. Office equipment will be procured in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement  Guidelines  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  will  be  transferred  to 
implementing agencies upon TA completion. The TA proceeds will be disbursed in line with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
13.  The TA will be implemented over 27 months (October 2010 to December 2012). ADB 
will  be  the executing  agency.  The  implementing  agencies  will  be  the  transport  ministries, 
customs  administrations,  inspection  and  quarantine  agencies,  and  other  agencies  with 
responsibilities for coordinated border management in the PRC and Mongolia. The ministries of 
finance in the PRC and Mongolia will be responsible for overall guidance and coordination with 
the respective domestic agencies, and will act as the main channel of communication with ADB. 
Private sector entities in the two countries, particularly in the border provinces concerned, will 
be engaged. The Financial Sector, Public Management and Regional Cooperation Division of 
ADB’s East Asia Department will administer and implement the TA in collaboration with the 
Central and West Asia Department and the PRC and Mongolia resident missions. Special 
attention will be paid to the potentially adverse impacts of trade facilitation and border-area 
development, particularly the risks of communicable disease and human and drug trafficking. 
Lessons from other projects in the two countries10 will be applied in the implementation of this 
TA project. The monitoring of implementation progress and outcome will be carried out through 
periodic reviews in accordance with the design and monitoring framework.  
 
14.  The TA outputs, particularly the findings and recommendations from the key studies, will 
be disseminated in the PRC and Mongolia and to other CAREC countries through workshops, 
seminars, conferences, publications, and the media. Where appropriate, representatives of the 
secretariats of other regional cooperation bodies will be invited to dissemination events.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $900,000 on a grant basis for 
the Development of Regional Cooperation Programs for Mongolia and the People’s Republic of 
China (Phase 2), and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Up to 12 person-months of international consultant and 20 person-months of 
national consultant inputs will be required to provide technical services to achieve the 
objectives of the regional policy and advisory technical assistance (TA). Given that some 
of the activities are still being planned, flexibility will be allowed and more detailed terms 
of  reference  for  specific  tasks  may  be  developed  later  in  consultation  with  the 
governments of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and Mongolia. The consultants 
will report to, and be supervised by, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) task manager(s) 
for the TA, who will also be responsible for the overall coordination of the TA activities. 
The reporting requirement for the international consultants will include (i) an inception 
report that includes a work schedule within 2 weeks of mobilization; (ii) a draft final report 
2 weeks before the end of the contract for review and comments by ADB and the 
governments; and (iii) a final report in hard and soft copies, incorporating all comments. 
The final reports—and the appendixes, if deemed necessary—will be translated into 
national languages. 
 
A.  International Consultants (12 person-months) 
 
2.  Customs cooperation specialist (3 person-months). An international customs 
cooperation specialist, with at least 10 years of working experience in regional customs 
cooperation,  adequate  experience  in  customs  modernization  efforts  in  developing 
countries, and postgraduate degrees, will be engaged to 
(i)  assist  PRC  and  Mongolian  customs  authorities  in  reviewing  the 
experience of the pilot phase of joint customs control (JCC) and designing 
practical and innovative approaches to implementing the second phase of 
JCC in selected customs houses, with a focus on priority corridors; 
(ii)  assist  PRC  and  Mongolian  customs  agencies  in  realigning  customs 
modernization and reform efforts with the strategic directions advocated 
by  the World  Customs  Organization  in  its  recently approved  strategy 
paper Customs in the 21st Century,1 focusing on achieving coordinated 
border management; 
(iii)  recommend measures to develop and improve the liaison and dialogue 
mechanism  between  PRC  and  Mongolian  customs  authorities  for 
customs  intelligence  exchange  and  management,  including  a 
coordination  mechanism  for  law  enforcement  agencies  in  the  two 
countries; 
(iv)  design and implement specialized training courses for customs officials, 
including arranging study tours to observe implementation of successful 
JCC,  corridor  performance  monitoring,  and  prevention  of  customs 
offenses;  
(v)  provide technical advisory services to the PRC and Mongolia on other 
priority  areas  identified  by  the  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic 
Cooperation  (CAREC)  Customs  Cooperation  Committee,  including 
simplification  and  harmonization  of  customs  procedures  and 
documentation, risk management and post-entry audit, information and 
communication  technology  for  customs  modernization  and  data 
exchange, and regional transit development;

through Trade Facilitation and Border Security. Brussels.

10  Appendix 3 
(vi)  design and help conduct the activities to share JCC experienced with 
Kazakhstan and other CAREC countries as appropriate; and  
(vii)  provide other technical services as required by PRC’s and Mongolia’s 
customs and the ADB project officer. 
 
3.  Development  economist  and  regional  cooperation  specialist  (3  person-
months). An international development economist and regional cooperation specialist 
will  be  hired  to  help  form  the  PRC–Mongolia  joint  committee  for  border-area 
development  and  management  at  Erenhot  and  Zamyn-Uud,  and  conduct  capacity 
building activities. The specialist will have at least 10 years of experience in cross-border 
trade  and  investment facilitation and 7  years of  experience  in  free  economic  zone 
development, and postgraduate degrees in economics and other fields of development. 
The consultant will  
(i)  review international best practices in common border-area development 
and cross-border free economic zone development and management, 
and recommend those that could be adapted to the PRC and Mongolia, 
with due attention to the need to address associated cross-border social, 
health, and environmental risks;  
(ii)  help design the architecture and implementation arrangements for the 
PRC–Mongolia joint committee and subcommittees, if necessary, for the 
sustainable management and development of the common border area at 
Erenhot and Zamyn-Uud, including drawing up the terms of reference, 
institutional and membership structure, and operational modalities; 
(iii)  review the mechanisms in the PRC and Mongolia regarding border-area 
development and free economic zone management, identify gaps, and 
recommend solutions that could be adapted to Erenhot and Zamyn-Uud; 
(iv)  review existing reports and studies on economic corridor development 
including CAREC and the Greater Mekong Subregion, and draw lessons 
applicable to the PRC and Mongolian contexts; 
(v)  assess  the  capacities  of  the  PRC  and  Mongolian  governments, 
particularly at the border levels, with regard to cross-border trade and 
investment facilitation and border-area development, and determine the 
training needs in these areas; 
(vi)  design  and  help  organize  well-targeted  workshops  and  other  training 
activities for the PRC and Mongolian government agencies and other 
stakeholders, particularly those at the border level;  
(vii)  prepare  training  materials  for  the  joint  committee,  including  manuals, 
guidelines and procedures, and instructions; and  
(viii)  help organize workshops to disseminate the lessons learned in the TA 
implementation. 
 
4.  Transport facilitation specialist (3 person-months). An international transport 
facilitation  specialist,  with  at  least  7  years  of  experience  in  cross-border  transport 
agreement negotiation and implementation, 10 years of experience in cross-border trade 
facilitation, and postgraduate degrees, will be engaged to 
(i)  review the lessons and experience of implementing the PRC–Mongolia 
road transport agreement, and identify constraints in its implementation, 
taking  into  consideration  the  experience  of  implementing  similar 
agreements in other CAREC countries; 
(ii)  recommend necessary changes to be incorporated in future amendments 
to the PRC–Mongolia road transport agreement, taking into consideration

Appendix 3  11 
the need to ensure maximum consistency with the cross-border transport 
agreement being negotiated under the broader CAREC framework;  
(iii)  identify institutional and human capacity gaps in the PRC and Mongolia 
with  regard  to  cross-border  transport  facilitation,  and  recommend 
measures to address them; 
(iv)  design and help conduct training workshops and other capacity-building 
activities to strengthen the transport facilitation capacity in the PRC and 
Mongolia, particularly at the local and border levels;  
(v)  design training materials, including manuals on implementing the PRC–
Mongolia transport agreement targeted at key user groups; 
(vi)  review the experience of negotiating cross-border transport agreements 
in  Asia  and  the  Pacific,  draw  lessons  applicable  to  negotiating  the 
tripartite transport agreement among the PRC, Mongolia, and the Russian 
Federation,  and  recommend  measures  to  revitalize  the  negotiation 
process of the tripartite agreement; and  
(vii)  design  and  help  conduct  activities  of  experience  sharing  with  other 
CAREC countries with regard to implementation of transport agreements.  
 
5.  Inspection  and  quarantine  specialist  (3  person-months).  An  international 
inspection and quarantine specialist, with at least 10 years of experience in cross-border 
inspection and quarantine cooperation and postgraduate degrees, will be engaged to 
help  set  up  a  mechanism  for  PRC–Mongolia  cooperation  in  the  inspection  and 
quarantine area and facilitate trade of agricultural products (particularly meat and dairy). 
The consultant will 
(i)  assess the barriers to trade of agricultural products (particularly meat and 
dairy) along the PRC–Mongolia border crossing points, identify the key 
concerns of the two countries, and design a mechanism for enhancing 
bilateral cooperation to address these concerns;  
(ii)  examine  current  practices  of  performing  quarantine  and  veterinary 
inspection, laboratory testing, and issuance of quarantine permits in the 
PRC  and  Mongolia;  identify gaps  in practice  based on  internationally 
accepted standards; and recommend measures to address quarantine 
and inspection issues to facilitate the export and import of meat and dairy 
products between the two countries;  
(iii)  assess the adequacy of facilities and equipment to perform the tests 
accurately and in a timely manner; and  
(iv)  assess the capacities of inspection and quarantine staff at the border 
posts to perform their functions, identify training needed to enhance such 
capacities, and develop a basic training program for the two countries on 
inspection and quarantine procedures. 
 
B.  National Consultants (20 person-months) 
 
6.  National consultants will be recruited to assist the international consultants by 
researching  and  compiling  government  policies  and  procedures,  collecting  data, 
translating  documents,  and  ensuring  that  the  work  produced  by  the  international 
consultants meets regional and national needs. They should also have good contacts 
with the public and private sectors. The national consultants will be supervised by the 
international consultants and by the ADB task manager.

12  Appendix 3 
7.  Customs  cooperation  specialist  (6  person-months  in  total,  with 3 person-
months each for the PRC and Mongolia). A PRC national consultant and a Mongolian 
national  consultant,  with  at  least  7  years  of  working  experience  in  customs 
modernization  and  regional  customs  cooperation,  will  be  engaged  to  help  the 
international customs cooperation specialist undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  assist  PRC  and  Mongolian  customs  authorities  in  reviewing  the 
experience  of  the  pilot  phase  of  JCC  and  designing  practical  and 
innovative  approaches  to  implementing  the  second  phase  of  JCC  in 
selected customs houses, with a focus on priority corridors; 
(ii)  recommend measures to strengthen PRC–Mongolia customs cooperation 
in other priority areas identified by the CAREC Customs Cooperation 
Committee; 
(iii)  assist  PRC  and  Mongolian  customs  agencies  in  realigning  customs 
modernization and reform efforts with the strategic directions advocated 
by  the World  Customs  Organization  in  its  recently approved  strategy 
paper Customs in the 21st Century, focusing on achieving coordinated 
border management; 
(iv)  recommend measures to develop and improve the liaison and dialogue 
mechanism  between the  PRC  and  Mongolian customs authorities for 
customs  intelligence  exchange  and  management,  including  a 
coordination  mechanism  for  law  enforcement  agencies  in  the  two 
countries; and 
(v)  design and implement specialized training courses for customs officials, 
including arranging study tours to observe implementation of successful 
JCC,  corridor  performance  monitoring,  and  prevention  of  customs 
offenses.  
 
8.  Development economist (6 person-months in total, with 3 person-months each 
for  the  PRC  and  Mongolia).  A  PRC  national  consultant  and  a  Mongolian  national 
consultant, with postgraduate degrees in economics or other fields of development and 
at least 5 years of experience in cross-border trade and economic cooperation, will be 
hired  to  help  the  international  development  economist  and  regional  cooperation 
specialist undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  review international best practices in common border-area development 
and cross-border free economic zone development and management, 
and recommend those that could be adapted to the PRC and Mongolia;  
(ii)  help design the architecture and implementation arrangements for the 
PRC–Mongolia joint committee, and subcommittees if necessary, for the 
sustainable management and development of the common border area at 
Erenhot and Zamyn-Uud; 
(iii)  review the mechanisms in the PRC and Mongolia regarding border-area 
development and free economic zone management, identify gaps, and 
recommend solutions that could be adapted to Erenhot and Zamyn-Uud; 
(iv)  assess  the  capacities  of  the  PRC  and  Mongolian  governments, 
particularly at the border levels, with regard to cross-border trade and 
investment facilitation and border-area development, and determine the 
training needs in these areas; 
(v)  design  and  help  organize  well-targeted  workshops  and  other  training 
activities for the PRC and Mongolian government agencies and other 
stakeholders, particularly those at the border level;

Appendix 3  13 
(vi)  prepare  training  materials  for  the  joint  committee,  including  manuals, 
guidelines and procedures, and instructions; and  
(vii)  help organize workshops to disseminate the lessons learned during TA 
implementation. 
 
9.  Transport  facilitation  specialist  (8  person-months  in  total,  with  4  person-
months each for the PRC and Mongolia). A PRC national consultant and a Mongolian 
national  consultant,  with  at  least  7  years  of  experience  in  the  transport  sector, 
particularly cross-border trade facilitation, and postgraduate degrees, will be engaged to 
help the international transport facilitation specialist undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  review  the  PRC’s  and  Mongolia’s  lessons  and  experience  in 
implementing the PRC–Mongolia road transport agreement, and identify 
obstacles and constraints in implementation; 
(ii)  recommend necessary changes to be incorporated in future amendments 
to the PRC–Mongolia road transport agreement;  
(iii)  identify institutional and human capacity gaps in the PRC and Mongolia 
with  regard  to  cross-border  transport  facilitation  and  recommend 
measures to address them; 
(iv)  help conduct training workshops and other capacity building activities to 
strengthen  transport  facilitation  capacity  in  the  PRC  and  Mongolia, 
particularly at the local and border levels;  
(v)  design training materials, including manuals on implementing the PRC–
Mongolia transport agreement targeted at key user groups; and  
(vi)  review the PRC’s and Mongolia’s experience in negotiating the cross-
border transport agreement; draw lessons applicable to the negotiation of 
a  tripartite  transport  agreement  among  the  PRC,  Mongolia,  and  the 
Russian  Federation;  and  make  recommendations  to  revitalize  the 
negotiations for the tripartite agreement.  
 
C.  Resource Persons (international and national) 
 
10.  Resource persons may be engaged to assist in the preparation of, attend, or 
present  to  conferences,  seminars,  and  training  events  organized  under  the  TA.  In 
exceptional cases, ADB staff with special knowledge and experience related to the TA 
may be engaged as resource persons.
